##

### <font size="16">What is <img src="Images/StackOverflow.png" height="100px" /> ?</font>
<br/><br/>

- Programming Q/A site launched September 15, 2008 created by Jeff Atwood and Joel Spolsky
- Built as an open alternative to Q/A tech sites such as Experts Exchange
- Fosters a gaming style with awarded points and badges to various milestones
- Rigorous, engaged community with moderators voted by users

## StackExchange Network

<div style="float: right; margin: -100px 0 0 0;"><img src="Images/R_StackOverflow.png" width="100px"/></div>

- Due to popularity becomes flagship site in [SE network](https://stackexchange.com/sites#)

<div class="wrapper"><img src="Images/StackExchangeSites.png"/></div>  


## Core of StackOverflow

<div style="float: right; margin: -100px 0 0 0;"><img src="Images/R_StackOverflow.png" width="100px"/></div>

- Users 
    - **Askers**: Usually one-off, newcomers who ask few questions
    - **Answerers**: Usually long-term, advanced members 
    - **Moderators**: Appointed and voted members of community to manage site
- Posts
    - Helps individual original posters (OPs)
    - Serves greater community/future readers
- Tags
    - Usually languages (C#, Java, Python, R)
    - Frameworks, tools, and modules (i.e., pandas, dplyr)
- Reputation and Badges
    - Fosters gaming competition
    - Signals expertise to community

## Best Practices - Askers

<div style="float: right; margin: -100px 0 0 0;"><img src="Images/R_StackOverflow.png" width="100px"/></div>

- Understand asking a good question is heard
- Research and debug enough (SO as last resort)
- Set up a [Minimum, Reproducible Example (MRE)](https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example)
- [How to make a great R reproducible example](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5963269/how-to-make-a-great-r-reproducible-example)

## Best Practices - Answerers 

<div style="float: right; margin: -100px 0 0 0;"><img src="Images/R_StackOverflow.png" width="100px"/></div>

- Balance speed, efficiency, and accuracy. 
- Do not expect very simple answer.
- Demonstrate code with data output and/or graph.
- Provide detailed explanation and in-line code comments for future readers.
- Search carefully for good attempts with reproducible examples.
- Work through your comfortable skillsets: 
    - Good with wrangling: `[r] [list]`, `[r] [dataframe]`, `[r] [loop]`
    
## Challenges/Lessons Learned

<div style="float: right; margin: -100px 0 0 0;"><img src="Images/R_StackOverflow.png" width="100px"/></div>

- Askers
    - Not too invested with curated repository
    - Often do not care about craft or learning process
    - Passive group who comes and goes
- Answerers 
    - Rigorous group that will challenge you
    - Can over-help for rep points without best practices
    - Can over-suggest packages such as tidyverse
- Advanced users 
    - Can pose as bullies and intimidate newcomers
    - StackOverflow Code of Conduct: https://stackoverflow.com/conduct


## Example Random Dataset

<div style="float: right; margin: -100px 0 0 0;"><img src="Images/R_StackOverflow.png" width="100px"/></div>

```{r echo = TRUE}
set.seed(6152019)
alpha <- c(LETTERS, letters, c(0:9))
data_tools <- c("sas", "stata", "spss", "python", "r", "julia")

random_df <- data.frame(
  group = sample(data_tools, 500, replace=TRUE),
  int = sample(1:15, 500, replace=TRUE),
  num = rnorm(500),
  char = replicate(500, paste(sample(alpha, 3, replace=TRUE), collapse="")),
  bool = sample(c(TRUE, FALSE), 500, replace=TRUE),
  date = as.Date(sample(1:as.integer(Sys.Date()), 500, replace=TRUE), origin="1970-01-01")
)

head(random_df)
```


## CRUG Groups to Answer Questions

<div class="wrapper"><img src="Images/header-background.png"></div>

- Break up into ~5 person(s) group, varying in expertise (novice to advanced)
- Designate one person to launch R (e.g., R shell, RStudio, Rgui) on computer
- Search for live questions: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/r
- Brainstorm and test as a team to figure solution
- Designate someone to type and submit notebook (PR or email)
